metadata.case_name: I.G. Investment Trust v. Raja of Khalikote

facts.text: Predecessor-in-title of respondents executed first mortgage on October 23, 1903, securing £1,35,000, completely redeemed in 1935.
Second mortgage executed on December 18, 1906, under which mortgagor borrowed £77,500 at 6% per annum.
Third mortgage executed on October 21, 1935, under which mortgagor borrowed £65,000; liability substantially accepted by Claims Officer and High Court.
Appellant received £1,77,349 by way of interest under 1906 mortgage, more than twice the principal.
Appellant gave credit for £29,000 towards principal under 1906 mortgage, leaving balance of £48,500 principal plus £17,460 interest up to May 1, 1953, plus commission and premium.
Mortgagor repudiated liability under 1906 mortgage on September 14, 1947, claiming extinction under s.10 Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 due to excess interest paid.
Appellant obtained ex parte decree in London for 1906 mortgage; execution failed in India per Calcutta High Court in I.G. Investment Trust v. Raja of Khalikote, AIR 1952 Cal. 508.
Mortgaged properties vested in State of Orissa on June 1, 1953, under Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951, via notification under s.3.
Appellant filed claim petition before Claims Officer under s.18 Abolition Act for dues under 1906 and 1935 mortgages, providing details of properties, payments, and equivalents in Indian currency.

Mortgagor contested claim before Claims Officer, pleading extinction under ss.10,11 (excess interest) and s.17 (possessory mortgage, 15 years possession) of Money-Lenders Act, and objections to commission/premium.
Claims Officer held 1906 mortgage extinguished under s.17 Money-Lenders Act (possessory, 15 years possession), rejected claim; declined ss.10,11 as not a court/suit.
Both parties appealed to Board (Orissa High Court) under s.21 Abolition Act.

Orissa High Court (Board) on January 4, 1963, held no possession for s.17, but applied ss.10,11 Money-Lenders Act with s.20(1) Abolition Act, extinguished mortgage as interest £1,77,349 exceeded principal, rejected claim including premium/commission.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss.10 and 11 of Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 apply to determination of claim by Claims Officer under s.20(1) Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951, to find if principal amount legally and justly due.
Whether 1906 mortgage liability extinguished under ss.10,11 Money-Lenders Act due to excess interest paid.
Whether Claims Officer must consider legal impediments like Money-Lenders Act provisions when determining 'legally and justly due' under Abolition Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Abolition Act is self-contained code; Claims Officer must follow only s.20(2) clauses a-f, no recourse to Money-Lenders Act ss.10,11 as no reference in Abolition Act.
Provisions of Money-Lenders Act and Abolition Act cannot apply to same transaction due to different calculation methods.

respondent_arguments.text: Mortgage extinguished under ss.10,11 Money-Lenders Act as interest paid exceeds principal; repudiated in 1947; Claims Officer/Board must determine 'legally and justly due' per Abolition Act ss.18(1)(a),20(1) by applying Money-Lenders Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 ss.10,11; Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 ss.18(1)(a),20(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Board has wider jurisdiction as tribunal to apply Money-Lenders Act for relief to debtor.

court_reasoning.text: To determine principal 'legally and justly due' under Abolition Act s.20(1), Claims Officer must check if claim legally enforceable in court, free of legal infirmity; thus apply Money-Lenders Act ss.10,11.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expression 'legally and justly due' requires considering statutes like Money-Lenders Act; if court would not enforce claim due to excess interest, Claims Officer cannot recognize it.

court_reasoning.text: Admitted interest £1,77,349 > twice principal £77,500; under s.10(2) Money-Lenders Act, excess interest appropriates to principal, no balance due.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mortgage liability extinguished; no further principal or interest payable.

court_reasoning.text: Claims Officer considers pleas like discharge or limitation before applying s.20(2); ss.10,11 applicable despite no specific reference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Abolition Act not intended to worsen creditor position vs. Money-Lenders Act relief.

holdings.text: Provisions of ss.10,11 Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 applicable by Claims Officer under s.20(1) Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 to determine if amount legally and justly due.
1906 mortgage extinguished under ss.10,11 Money-Lenders Act as interest paid exceeds principal; no amount due.

precedents_cited.case_name: I.G. Investment Trust v. Raja of Khalikote
precedents_cited.relevance: Held London decree not executable in India.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates interest; extinguishes debt if interest >= principal (s.10); possessory mortgage after 15 years (s.17); applicable to determine legal debt under Abolition Act.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of estates; claims procedure; Claims Officer determines principal 'legally and justly due'; Board (High Court) appeals.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; upheld High Court (Board) decision that no amount payable under 1906 mortgage as extinguished under ss.10,11 Money-Lenders Act applied via s.20(1) Abolition Act due to excess interest paid.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in any other law... no Court shall... pass a decree for an amount of interest... greater than the amount of the loan originally advanced."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.10(1) Money-Lenders Act, basis for extinguishment.

key_quotes.text: The expression 'legally and justly due' must... mean that... such a claim, if sought to be enforced in a Court... does not suffer from any legal infirmity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for applying Money-Lenders Act to Abolition Act claims.

key_quotes.text: If no Court would have recognized the present claim of the appellant, the same principles must be applicable when the Claims Officer is also called upon... to determine the principal amount legally and justly due.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Links enforceability in court to Claims Officer duty.
